questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following is not a component of innate immunity?
questions.explanation:
B cell is not a component of innate immunity. It is a component of adaptive immunity. Innate immunity refers to the body’s natural immunity. It is a built-in defence system that is 
present since birth. It differs from adaptive immunity in that it does not require any prior 
sensitization to an antigen. The major components of innate immunity are as follows: • Epithelial barriers that block the entry of microbes 263 
Sold by @itachibot • Phagocytic cells (neutrophils and macrophages) • Natural killer (NK) cells • Dendritic cell • Cells that can sense and react to microbes - mast cells, epithelial and endothelial cells • Plasma proteins - complement system factors, mannose-binding lectin, and C-reactive protein • Innate lymphoid cells • Lung surfactant

questions.question: Question 3: Antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC) is seen with:
questions.explanation:
Antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC) is mediated by NK cells, neutrophils and 
eosinophils (killing certain parasitic worms like helminths via IgE antibodies). In ADCC, cells/ antigens are coated with IgG antibodies. These are killed by effector cells like NK 
cells and macrophages. These effector cells bind to the target by their receptors for the Fc 
fragment of IgG and cell lysis proceeds without phagocytosis.

questions.question: Question 4: Which of the following occurs due to gain-of-function mutations in NOD-Like receptors?
questions.explanation:
The gain of function mutations in NOD-Like receptors (NLRs) result in periodic fever syndromes 
called autoinflammatory syndromes. They are a group of clinical conditions characterised by recurrent inflammatory episodes. This 
disorder is marked by abnormally increased inflammation, mediated predominantly by cells and 
molecules of the innate immune system, with a significant host predisposition. NOD-like receptors are cytosolic receptors that signal via a cytosolic multiprotein complex called 
the inflammasome. This activates caspase-1 that generates biologically active form of interleukin-1 
(IL-1). IL-1 is a mediator of inflammation that recruits leukocytes and induces fever. The 
autoinflammatory syndromes respond very well to treatment with IL-1 antagonists. Note: Autoimmune diseases result from T and B-lymphocyte reactions against self-antigens.

questions.question: Question 5: What is the normal CD4+: CD8+ T lymphocyte ratio?
questions.explanation:
Normal CD4+: CD8+ T lymphocyte ratio is 2:1. Approximately 60% of mature T cells are CD4+ 
and about 30% are CD8+. T-lymphocytes (thymus-derived cells) constitute 60–70% of peripheral blood lymphocytes. T-cell 
progenitors are derived from the bone marrow, but travel to the thymus, where they mature. T 
cells can be divided into three main subtypes: They are located in the paracortical areas of lymph nodes and the periarteriolar sheaths of 
the spleen. They have an antigen-specific T-cell receptors (TCR) which have alpha/beta 
polypeptide chains components. Demonstration of TCR gene rearrangement by southern blot is a 
molecular marker of T-cell lineage. The CD molecules present on T cells are CD1, CD2, CD3, CD4, CD5, CD7, CD8 and CD28. CD3 is 
involved in signal transduction and is also called a pan T-cell marker. CD40 ligand on the surface 
is required for B-cell activation and induction of immunoglobulin. 266

questions.question: Question 6: Which of the following is not expressed in the B-cell receptor complex?
questions.explanation:
CD86 is a protein expressed on antigen-presenting cells, and not B-cell receptor complex. This 
protein provides costimulatory signals necessary for T-cell activation and survival. B-cell receptor complex expresses the following: • CD79a and CD79b - essential for signal transduction through the antigen receptor • CD21 or CR2 - complement receptor (recognize complement products during innate immune 
response) and Epstein–Barr virus (EBV) receptor • CD40 - receives signals from helper T cells Other B cell-associated markers are CD10 (CALLA), CD19, CD20, CD22, CD23.

questions.question: Question 7: Which of the following are the most important antigen-presenting cells?
questions.explanation:
Dendritic cells or interdigitating dendritic cells are the most important antigen-presenting 
cells. They initiate T-cell responses against protein antigens. They are located in the epithelium and interstitium. They express many receptors for capturing 
and responding to microbes (and other antigens), including toll-like receptors (TLRs) and lectins. 
They also express high levels of major histocompatibility complex (MHC) for presenting antigens 
to and activating T cells. In response to microbes, dendritic cells are recruited to the T-cell zones of lymphoid organs. Here, 
they present antigens to T cells with help of MHC. Similar cells with dendritic morphology in the germinal centers of lymphoid follicles in the spleen 
and lymph nodes are follicular dendritic cells. They bear Fc receptors for IgG and receptors for 
C3b. Immature dendritic cells within the epidermis are called Langerhans cells. Note: • Aggretope - part of the antigen associated with the MHC molecule on the antigen-presenting cell • Epitope - antigenic part of contact with the T-cell receptor 267 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 8: Which of the following statements is false about macrophages?

options.a: It acts as an antigen presenting cell
options.b: It plays a role in humoral immunity
options.c: It plays a role in cell-mediated immunity
options.d: It is a component of innate immunity only

questions.explanation:
Macrophages are components of both innate and acquired immunity. They phagocytose microbes and protein antigens. They process the antigens and present the 
peptide fragments to T cells. Thus, macrophages function as antigen-presenting cells in T-cell 
activation. They also participate in the effector phase of humoral immunity. Macrophages efficiently 
phagocytose and destroy microbes that are opsonized (coated) with IgG or C3b. They are key effector cells in certain forms of cell-mediated immunity to eliminate intracellular 
microbes. In this type of response, T cells activate macrophages and enhance their ability to kill 
ingested microbes.

questions.question: Question 9: Which of the following is false about natural killer cells?

options.a: CD16 and CD56 are the surface molecules
options.b: They are involved in antibody-dependant cytotoxic killing
options.c: IL-12 stimulates the proliferation of NK cells
options.d: They activate macrophages by secreting IFN-

questions.explanation:
IL-2 and IL-15 stimulate the proliferation of NK cells. On the other hand, IL-12 activates the 
killing of target cells and secretion of IFN-. NK cells are large granular lymphocytes, which constitutes 5% to 10% of peripheral blood 
lymphocytes. CD16 and CD56 are the surface molecules. Functions of NK cells: • Killing of a variety of virus-infected cells and tumor cells, without prior exposure to or activation 
by these microbes or tumors • Secretion of interferon- (IFN-), which activates macrophages to destroy ingested microbes • Antibody-dependent cell-mediated cytotoxicity (ADCC) - NK cells express CD16 which is a 
receptor for IgG Fc tails. Hence, these cells have the ability to lyse IgG-coated target cells. ADCC is also seen in immune responses involving neutrophils, eosinophils, macrophages, etc. The image given below shows activating and inhibitory receptors of natural killer (NK) cells. 268 
Sold by @itachibot Note: A new group of T cells has been discovered called NK-T cells. These are T cells that contain 
markers of NK cells. These are important defence mechanisms against microorganisms like 
Listeria monocytogenes and Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

questions.question: Question 10: Which of these is common to both cytotoxic T-cells and NK cells?

options.a: They are MHC l restricted cells
options.b: Require antibodies to be present for action

questions.explanation:
Both cytotoxic T-cells and NK cells are effective against virus-infected cells. The NK cells have different mechanisms of action while killing target cells. NK cells can lyse IgG-coated target cells by binding to the Fc tail of IgG, through the CD16 
receptor expressed on NK cells. This phenomenon is known as antibody-dependent cellular 
cytotoxicity (ADCC). NK cells secrete various cytokines such as interferon- (IFN-), which activate macrophages to 
destroy ingested microbes. Target cell destruction by NK cells is also mediated through two others receptors - activating 
receptors and inhibitory receptors. The activating receptors enable NK cells to recognize infected and stressed cells. The inhibitory 
receptors recognize self class-I MHC molecules, that are expressed on all healthy cells thereby 
preventing NK cells from killing normal cells. Virus infection / neoplastic transformation 
overexpresses the activating receptors and simultaneously reduces the expression of class-I MHC 
molecules. As a result, NK cells are activated and the infected cells are killed. CD8+ cytotoxic T lymphocytes directly kill damaged cells. The differences between NK cells and cytotoxic T-cells are: Natural killer (NK) cell

questions.question:
Question 11: Which of the following markers on antigen-presenting cells function as costimulatory 
molecules for T cells?
questions.explanation:
CD80 (B7-1) and CD86 (B7-2) are the costimulatory molecules present on antigen-presenting cells 
(APCs). They bind to CD28 protein present on T cells. This promotes the expansion of 
antigen-stimulated T cells and their differentiation into effector and memory cells. T-cell activation requires two signals that are delivered by APCs. They include: • Antigens displayed by APCs in the form of peptides bound to MHC 
molecules, that are recognised by T-cell receptors • Costimulatory signal (as it stimulates T cells in conjunction with antigen) provided by molecules 
on APCs that engage particular costimulatory receptors on T cells In the absence of costimulation, T cells that recognize antigen either fail to respond and die or 
enter a state of unresponsiveness known as anergy. Thus, costimulation is a key determinant of 
the outcome of a T-cell encounter with an antigen.

questions.explanation:

questions.question: Question 13: B-cells are induced to produce IgE by which of the following:
questions.explanation: IL-4 stimulates B-cells to differentiate into IgE secreting plasma cells.

questions.question: Question 14: Production of which of the following antibodies is induced by polysaccharides and lipids?
questions.explanation:
Polysaccharides and lipids stimulate the secretion of mainly IgM antibodies. B lymphocytes use their antigen receptors to recognize various types of antigens: • Proteins (through CD40L and cytokine-mediated helper T-cell actions) - induce production of 
IgG, IgA, IgE • Polysaccharides and lipids - induce production of IgM mainly Helper T cells also help in antibodies by the mechanisms: • Stimulate formation of germinal centers which consist of proliferating B cells • Induce isotype switching through cytokines IFN- and IL-4 • Affinity maturation - stimulate the production of antigen-specific antibodies Isotype switching and affinity maturation occur mainly in germinal centers.

questions.question:
Question 15: When papain acts on a molecule of immunoglobulin, which of the following are the end 
products?
questions.explanation:
When papain acts on a molecule of immunoglobulin, the end products are 1 Fc and 2 Fab 
fragments. If an antibody molecule is digested with papain, cleavage occurs above the disulfide bonds that 
hold the heavy chains together. This generates 3 separate fragments, two of which are called Fab 
(fragment antigen binding), and one of which is called Fc (fragment crystallizable). The image given below shows the cleavage of immunoglobulin by papain. 271 
Sold by @itachibot Cleavage of the antibody molecule with pepsin generates one large fragment called F(ab´)2 and a 
digested Fc fragment. The image given below shows the cleavage of immunoglobulin by pepsin.

questions.question: Question 16: In which of the following cells is recirculation seen?

options.c: Both plasma cells and T lymphocytes
options.d: Both B lymphocytes and plasma cells

questions.explanation:
Lymphocyte recirculation is seen in T lymphocytes. Migration of the lymphocytes between blood and lymphoid organs is called recirculation. Naive 
lymphocytes traverse the peripheral lymphoid organs, where immune responses are 
initiated. When antigen-presenting cells activate them, the effector lymphocytes migrate to sites of 
infection and inflammation. 272 
Sold by @itachibot In contrast, plasma cells remain in lymphoid organs and the bone marrow. They do not need to 
migrate to sites of infection because they secrete antibodies that are carried to distant tissues.

questions.question: Question 17: Which of the following about ■ T-cells is incorrect:

options.a: Kills extracellular bacteria by granulysin and perforin
options.b: Need antigen processing and presentation for it recognition

questions.explanation: ■ T-cells do not need antigen processing and presentation for its recognition. There are two types of T cells: ■ T-cells and  T-cells. The functions of ■ T-cells: • Provide protection against mycobacteria by direct killing of infected macrophages • Kills extracellular bacteria by granulysin and perforin • Plays a role in maintaining self-tolerance • Capable of recognising and lysing diverse cancers in an MHC-unrestricted manner  T-cells have MHC restricted action.

questions.question: Question 18: Basophils are activated by:
questions.explanation: Basophils are activated by IL-5 and IL-3. Note: IL-5 primarily activates eosinophils.

questions.question: Question 19: Among the following, which cells have MHC class II?

options.c: B cells, dendritic cells, mononuclear phagocytes

questions.explanation:
Class II major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecules are mainly expressed 
on macrophages, B lymphocytes, and dendritic cells. These cells present ingested antigens to 
T-cells. The function of MHC molecules is to display peptide fragments of protein antigens for recognition 
by antigen-specific T cells. In humans, the MHC molecules are called human leukocyte antigens 
(HLA) because they were initially detected on leukocytes by the binding of antibodies. The 
combination of HLA alleles in each individual is called the HLA haplotype. The genes encoding HLA molecules are clustered on the short arm of chromosome 6. Uses of MHC/ HLA typing include: • Anthropology • Transfusion • Paternity testing • Forensic science • Transplantation 273 
Sold by @itachibot • Disease correlation

questions.question: Question 20: Which of the following is not encoded by MHC class III genes?
questions.explanation:
 2 microglobulin associated cell surface molecules are encoded by MHC class I and not class III. Class III MHC molecules include: • Complement proteins (such as C2, C4, and B factor) • Cytokines (such as TNF-, LTA, and LTB) • Properdin factor BQ of alternate pathway • Enzyme tyrosine hydroxylase • Heat-shock proteins Class III molecules are encoded by genes located between those that encode class I and class II 
molecules. 274
